page.lettertext:
fol.23r
S
r
. This bearer
S
r
Francis Vere
retorneth soe fully
instructed both w
th
the cause whie he was sent for, and with [.]
matters committed to his charge, to be furthered by yowe, as I [.]
not inlarge the same by anie writinge: But this I doe add
hir
Ma
ties
Commaundment, that she is vearie desirous to h[ave]
the
States
stand firme from givinge [Eare] from the [pipinge] of
the
Arc h
d
. I meane the Archduke to anie turne: & likewise if
Mons
r
Sanly showld com thither for anie further aide to be had of
the States, that except theie maie be assured that the
French
K
. will make noe peace nor truce w
th
the
K. of Spaine
, they
cannot w
th
theire suretie yeld unto him anie aide: the mann[er]
howe to procure this firme resoluc
o
n in the States I must leave
it to yo
r
owne best Considerac
o
n./
Yo
r
last letters concerning the opinion yowe had of
e yelding
to the platt office for satsifac
o
n of the Queene by yo
r
secrett
meanes w
th
Barnevalt
did nothinge content her Ma
tie
, because
of the delaie of time for performance of the matter: But
I hope the succes of that yo
r
Negotiac
o
n beinge soe wise he
gouverned by yowe will better satisfie hir Ma
tie
then
hitherto she is./
And so by reason of my infinite [.]
time and lack of leisure I ende this l
re
beinge scarce
hable to signe the same w
th
my weake hand./ From
my howse in the strand this xviij
th
of Feb
1595
.
Yo
r
assured loving frend./
William Burghley
